Award.AwardTitle: Canonical Metrics, Geometric Flows and Formation of Singularities
Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent progress and influx of new ideas have unraveled a deep, rich and unifying structure among analysis, Riemannian geometry, pluripotential theory, classical several complex variables and the minimal model program in algebraic geometry. The proposed research work focuses on a number of open problems and developing programs on canonical metrics, geometric flows and complex Monge-Ampere equations arising from geometry and physics. The proposed project also aims to bring in research and teaching innovation in mathematics from various disciplines and have an immediate beneficial effect on graduate and undergraduate students at Rutgers as well as in the regional community of mathematics. The PI will also organize and participate in the integrated research/education programs and activities that will promote the education level of the nation. Furthermore, the PI plans to disseminate the exciting frontier research at the interface of geometry, analysis and algebra to a broad audience through lectures and survey papers.

The PI will investigate and continue to make progress in the analytic minimal model program with Ricci flow. In particular, the PI will study both the finite time and long time formation of singularities of the Kahler-Ricci flow on algebraic varieties. Such singularity formation is reflected by canonical geometric/analytic surgeries equivalent to birational transformations and should be understood through global and local metric uniformization. The PI will also investigate the canonical metrics of Einstein type on singular varieties, in particular, the Riemannian geometric properties of such singular metrics and related moduli problems with applications in string theory such as geometric transitions and mirror symmetry. The PI willy employ new theories and techniques from L^2-theory, nonlinear PDEs, Perelman's works and Cheeger-Colding theory. The outcome of the proposed research will develop new tools and give profound insights of the structure of the universe as well as many other applied sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual metrit: 

There have been tremendous progress and influx of new ideas in the past 15 years that unraveled deep, rich and unifying structures among Ricci flow, Riemannian and metric geometry, pluripotential theory, classical several complex variables and the minimal model program in algebraic geometry. The proposed projects aim to apply such new ideas and techniques to open problems and new discoveries in complex geometry and analysis. The understanding of these problems help make fundamental progress in the study of analytic and geometric singularities arising from fully nonlinear partial differential equations in both physics and geometry. The following are the major outcomes of the award during the funding period.

The PI continued to investigate and make progress in the analytic minimal model program with Ricci flow proposed by the PI and Tian. For the short time singularity formation, the PI and his collaborators proved general convergence of the normalized Ricci flow on the 2-sphere with marked points and have classified the limiting structures in stable, semi-stable and unstable cases. With his graduate student Guo, the PI has shown that the Kahler-Ricci flow with initial metrics of suitable symmetries must develop mild singularities and the rescaled solutions converge smoothly to a complete Ricci soliton. The PI has also shown with his collaborators that the long time solutions of the Kahler-Ricci flow on minimal Kahler surfaces of general type always converge to a Kahler-Einstein surface with isolated orbifold singularities in Gromov-Hausdorff topology. 

The PI studied Riemannian geometry of canonical Kahler-Einstein currents on projective Calabi-Yau varieties and canonical models of general type with crepant singularities. The PI proved that the metric completion of the smooth part of such a canonical current is a compact metric space homeomorphic to the original algebraic variety, with well-defined tangent cones. This result establishes the conjectural picture that canonical analytic currents on algebraic varieties must share optimal geometric properties. Using such a new approach, the PI gives a new proof of Kawamata's famous base point free theorem on projective manifolds of general type by purely analytic method. 

The PI and his student Guo proved a sharp Schauder estimate for linear partial differential equations with singular background Riemannian metrics in an ambitious framework to study Riemannian geometry with singularities and their applications. More specifically, this result can be applied for deformation of canonical Kahler metrics with mild singularities such as conical singularities along hypersurfaces. 


Broader impact: 

Problems proposed projects by the PI arise naturally from attempts to under- stand nonlinear differential equations from geometry and physics. The PI has been studying the classification of Einstein spaces in the complex geometric setting and his research results on compactness of Kahler-Einstein metrics and singularity analysis of the Ricci flow will give both conceptual understanding and technical support to string theory and theoretical physics in general.  The PI has continued to organize the complex analysis and geometry seminar at Rutgers as well as workshops on global geometric analysis with various institutions. He has been hosting the graduate learning seminar on complex geometry and has built up a complex analysis group of junior researchers and graduate students at Rutgers. The PI has also supervised two undergraduate students for their summer research in mathematics. Furthermore, the PI has disseminated the exciting frontier research at the interface of geometry and analysis lectures at international conferences and survey papers.
